resourcesPipeline:
--tries=5 --mirror --no-parent --no-directories --no-host-directories --cut-dirs=2 --accept=gi_taxid_prot.dmp.gz,taxdump.tar.gz gunzip @downloadDir@/taxonomy/gi_taxid_prot.dmp.gz gunzip @downloadDir@/taxonomy/taxdump.tar.gz tar -xf @downloadDir@/taxonomy/taxdump.tar -C @downloadDir@/taxonomy/ rm -f @downloadDir@/taxonomy/taxdump.tar --names @downloadDir@/taxonomy/names.dmp --nodes @downloadDir@/taxonomy/nodes.dmp --gencode @downloadDir@/taxonomy/gencode.dmp --merged @downloadDir@/taxonomy/merged.dmp --restart @taxonomy.restart@ --verbose @commit@ The NCBI Taxonomy database contains the names of all organisms that are represented in the Entrez genetic databases. --tries=5 --output-document=so.obo --inputFile @downloadDir@/SO/so.obo --soVersion 1.176 --soCvsVersion 1.176 The Sequence Ontology Project (SO) is a joint effort by genome annotation centres, including: WormBase, the Berkeley Drosophila Genome Project, FlyBase, the Mouse Genome Informat ics group, and the Sanger Institute. They are a part of the Gene Ontology Project and their aim is to develop an ontology suitable for describing biological sequences. --tries=5 --mirror --no-parent --no-directories --no-host-directories --cut-dirs=3 --accept=enzclass.txt,enzyme.dat --InPath @downloadDir@/enzymeDB/ --enzymeDbName %EXT_DB_NAME% --enzymeDbRlsVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% @commit@ ENZYME is a repository of information relative to the nomenclature of enzymes. It is primarily based on the recommendations of the Nomenclature Committee of the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB) and it describes each type of characterized enzyme for which an EC (Enzyme Commission) number has been provided --tries=5 --output-document=evidence_code.obo --oboFile @downloadDir@/GO_evidence_codes/evidence_code.obo Gene Ontology annotation uses evidence codes to indicate the type of evidence that supports the annotation. --tries=5 --output-document=gene_ontology.obo --oboFile @downloadDir@/GO/gene_ontology.obo --extDbRlsName %EXT_DB_NAME% --extDbRlsVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% The Gene Ontology (GO) project provides a controlled vocabulary to describe gene and gene product attributes in any organism. --tries=5 --mirror --no-parent --no-directories --no-host-directories --cut-dirs=3 --accept=nr.gz --dbRefExternalDatabaseSpec "%EXT_DB_NAME%|%EXT_DB_RLS_VER%" The Non-Redundant Database (NRDB) of protein sequences in FASTA format from GenBank. fixSuperfamily @downloadDir@/InterproscanData/iprscan17.0/iprscan/data cp @downloadDir@/InterproscanData/iprscan17.0/insertInterpro-config.xml @downloadDir@/InterproscanData/iprscan17.0/iprscan/data --inPath @downloadDir@/InterproscanData/iprscan17.0/iprscan/data InterPro is a database of protein families, domains and functional sites in which identifiable features found in known proteins can be applied to unknown protein sequences. --sourceIdRegex "\|(\w+\(\S+\))$" --fastaFile @downloadDir@/WatanabeCpHNJ-1_PredictedTrancripts/reffull_cp.fas --externalDatabaseName %EXT_DB_NAME% --externalDatabaseVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --SOTermName 'transcript' --ncbiTaxId 5807 --libraryStage 'oocyst' --libraryVector 'pME18SFL3' --contactName 'Junichi Watanabe' --contactAddress1 "Institute of Medical Science; The University of Tokyo, Department of Parasitology" --contactAddress2 "4-6-1, Shirokanedai, Minatoku, Tokyo 108-8639, Japan" --putativeFullLength --libraryName 'derivedFromWatanabeCpHNJ-1' --libraryDesc "Predicted full length transcript sequence produced after BLAT alignment of the CpHNJ-1 EST library sequences to the genome and correction of the cDNA sequences using annotated gene sequences." J.Watanabe,H.Wakaguri1,M.Sasaki1,Y.Suzuki1,S.Sugano1 C. parvum HNJ-1 predicted full length transcript sequences. --sourceIdRegex "\|(\w+)$" --fastaFile @downloadDir@/WatanabeCpHNJ-1_EstLibrary/onepass_cp.fas --externalDatabaseName %EXT_DB_NAME% --externalDatabaseVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --SOTermName 'EST' --ncbiTaxId 5807 --libraryStage 'oocyst' --libraryVector 'pME18SFL3' --contactName 'Junichi Watanabe' --contactAddress1 "Institute of Medical Science; The University of Tokyo, Department of Parasitology" --contactAddress2 "4-6-1, Shirokanedai, Minatoku, Tokyo 108-8639, Japan" --libraryName 'WatanabeCpHNJ-1' --libraryDesc "C. parvum HNJ-1 strain (genotype 2) was originally isolated from a Japanese immunocompetent patient with diarrhea in 1989 and has been maintained by subinoculation in SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency) mice. Five-week old female SCID mice were infected by oral inoculation of 105 oocysts. Feces were collected in water under the cage and oocysts were purified by sugar floatation followed by diethyl ether method. Oocysts were incubated in 0.1N HCl at 37oC for 1 hour. After three washes with MEM they were incubated in MEM supplemented with 0.1% deoxycholate at 37oC for 30 min. Excysted sporozoites werehomogenized in Trizol (Invitrogen) using Polytron homogenizer and RNAs were isolated." Junichi Watanabe1, Hiroyuki Wakaguri2, Kazumi Abe2, Yutaka Suzuki2, Sumio Sugano2, Xuenan Xuan3 and Isao Kimata4
1Department of Parasitology, Institute of Medical Science. 2Department of Medical Genomics, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo. 3National Research Center for Protozoan Diseases, Obihoro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine. 4Department of Protozoal Diseases, Graduate School of Medicine, Osaka City University. --extDbName %EXT_DB_NAME% --extDbRlsVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --mapFile @gusHome@/lib/xml/isf/CryptoDB/cryptoGenbank2gus.xml --inputFileOrDir @downloadDir@/C.muris_scaffoldsGB/cma1.20080728.gbk --fileFormat genbank --soCvsVersion @soVer@ --organism "Cryptosporidium muris" --handlerExternalDbs "enzyme:enzymeDB:2008-07-22" --seqSoTerm "supercontig" Cryptosporidium muris sequence and annotation from Lis Caler and Hernan A. Proteome analysis was carried out on two components of the oocyst after excystation. (1) the proteins identified in the sporozoites and (2) the proteins identified belonging to residual oocyst wall. Furthermore, proteome analysis was also carried on the intact oocyst. Consequently, the aim of this study was to identify proteins unique to each subcellular component, and also to identify proteins shared between fractions --inputFile Center --inputFile @downloadDir@/Fiser_Proteomics_14Aug2006_1D_gel/14Aug2006_1D_gel --externalDatabaseSpec '%EXT_DB_NAME%|%EXT_DB_RLS_VER%' --geneExternalDatabaseSpec 'C.parvum scaffold from Genbank|2008-08-13' Peptides from LC-MS/MS analysisof C. parvum by the Albert Einstein Biodefense Proteomics Research Center mkdir @downloadDir@/IEDB_Epitopes_fixed createEpitopeFilesFromExcel --excelDir @downloadDir@/IEDB_Epitopes --outDir @downloadDir@/IEDB_Epitopes_fixed --seqFileDir @downloadDir@/IEDB_Epitopes_fixed/fasta --externalDatabaseName %EXT_DB_NAME% --externalDatabaseVersion %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --soTermName "protein_binding_site" --regexSourceId ">(\d+)|" --tableName "DoTS::MotifAASequence" --logFrequency 100 --regexTaxonName "\|.*\|(.*)\n" --regexName "\|(.*)\|.*\n" IEDB epitopes. createEpitopeDbRefFile --inputDir @downloadDir@/IEDB_Epitopes_fixed --outputFile @downloadDir@/IEDB_Epitopes_DBxRefs/dbRefs.txt --DbRefMappingFile @downloadDir@/IEDB_Epitopes_DBxRefs/dbRefs.txt --extDbName %EXT_DB_NAME% --extDbReleaseNumber %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --columnSpec "primary_identifier, remark" --tableName "AASequenceDbRef" IEDB epitopes. --dbRefExternalDatabaseSpec "%EXT_DB_NAME%|%EXT_DB_RLS_VER%" The C. parvum isolates MD (Okhuysen et al., 2002) and TU114 (Tanriverdi and Widmer, 2006) were selected as parentals isolates for a genetic cross. MD is a laboratory isolate originally derived from a deer and maintained by serial mouse passage. TU114 originates from a Ugandan child of unknown HIV status (Tumwine et al., 2003). The main criterion for selection of MD and TU114 was extensive genetic diversity between the isolates. Genetic diversity was determined with multiple micro- and minisatellite polymorphisms as described (Tanriverdi and Widmer, 2006). Isolates MD and TU114, were maintained and crossed in adult immunosuppressed C57BL/6 mice (1 mg dexamethasone phosphate administered every second day (Yang et al., 2000)). Six days after the first injection, mice were infected orally with ~1000 oocysts. Oocysts were purified from mouse feces as previously described (Widmer et al., 1998). Briefly, samples were homogenized and the oocysts floated on a 15%/30% (w/v) Histodenz (N,N'-bis(2,3-dihydroxypropyl)acetamido-2,4,6-tri-iodo-isophthalamide) (Sigma, St. Louis, Miss.) step gradient. Oocysts were sometimes further purified with immunomagnetic separation using the Aureon Crypto Kit (Aureon Biosystems, Vienna, Austria). DNA was extracted from purified oocysts with the High Pure Template Preparation Kit (Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, Ind.) (Tanriverdi et al., 2002). DNA was eluted in 20-50 ul TE buffer, a concentration equivalent to 10^4 oocysts/ul. SNPs differentiating the isolates MD and TU114 were identified by sequencing randomly chosen fragments of 2-2.5 kb retrieved from the C. parvum genome sequence. Fragments were spaced at approximately 80 kb. PCR primers 20-30 bp long were designed with vector NTI software. PCR included approximately 10 ng DNA of parental isolates MD or TU114, 0.4 µM primers and PCR mix (Takara) to a final volume of 50µl. Amplifications were performed with the following temperature condition: denaturation at 94°C for 2 min was followed by 35 cycles of 94°C for 30 s, 50-55°C for 30 sec, 68°C for 1.5 2 min, and a final 5 min extension at 68°C. A portion of 5µl of each PCR product was run on 1% agarose. For PCR reactions giving a single band, 5µl PCR product was treated with 2 µl of ExoSAP-IT (USB) at 37°C for 30 min and 80°C for 15 min. If multiple PCR bands were present, the entire PCR reaction was run on a 1% agarose gel and the desired band extracted with a QIAquick gel extraction. PCR products were sequenced using two pairs of primers of opposite polarity located at 700-800 bp intervals. Primers were designed such that adjacent complementary sequences overlapped by 50-100 bp. Portions of approximately 50 ng PCR product (~50 ng) were used in 15 µl sequencing reactions (CEQ DTCS-Quick Start Kit). Sequencing reactions were run on a CEQ8000 Genetic Analysis System (Beckman Coulter). Sequences were analyzed the Contig Express program in Vector NTI. MD and TU114 sequences were aligned to find SNPs. Any SNP was confirmed in a minimum of two sequences. Some SNPs were also confirmed by independent PCR amplification of the genomic DNA .

References cited in Summary:
Okhuysen, P.C., Rich, S.M., Chappell, C.L., Grimes, K.A., Widmer, G., Feng, X., and Tzipori, S. (2002) Infectivity of a Cryptosporidium parvum isolate of cervine origin for healthy adults and interferon-gamma knockout mice. J Infect Dis 185: 1320-1325.
Tanriverdi, S., and Widmer, G. (2006) Differential evolution of repetitive sequences in Cryptosporidium parvum and Cryptosporidium hominis. Infect Genet Evol 6: 113-122.
Tumwine, J.K., Kekitiinwa, A., Nabukeera, N., Akiyoshi, D.E., Rich, S.M., Widmer, G., Feng, X., and Tzipori, S. (2003) Cryptosporidium parvum in children with diarrhea in Mulago Hospital, Kampala, Uganda. Am J Trop Med Hyg 68: 710-715.
Yang, S., Benson, S.K., Du, C., and Healey, M.C. (2000) Infection of immunosuppressed C57BL/6N adult mice with a single oocyst of Cryptosporidium parvum. J Parasitol 86: 884-887.
Widmer, G., Tzipori, S., Fichtenbaum, C.J., and Griffiths, J.K. (1998) Genotypic and phenotypic characterization of Cryptosporidium parvum isolates from people with AIDS. J Infect Dis 178: 834-840.
